author: @ErazerPT
text:
While i loathe SaaS, you have to give the Devil it's due. You're not just paying for the "software". You're paying for a) the people that keep it running, and that is people developing, people maintaining, people supporting it and b) depending on the software, the interop with the "larger ecosystem". If b is unavoidable, you're stuck. a is the touchy one, because it's a balance of scales. It makes sense to DIY IF the cost of subs is considerably larger than the "man hour" cost of DIY OR you can't really afford the service.
It all comes down to the old "nobody wants a power drill, everyone wants holes drilled". The vast majority wants the end result not the tool. That SaaS is now "the Devil" is more to the insane pricing and abusive conditions of the services than the services model itself.

text: Complete disregard for the business side of things. All those subscriptions are worth it to a business since it's very cheap and allows you to iterate much faster: you also get official support, something most open-source projects don't offer (like, I have to ask to pay to get help from a maintainer, it isn't included in a nice, predictable expense). Sure, you might not like subscriptions, but a business does since it's predictable. Also, as for self-hosting all these tools: almost never do you need to export data, almost never is your hosting more reliable than the company's. In sociology there's this way of looking at things like you would do in UNIX: one thing that does one thing only and does it well. By this I mean that I don't want to do everything, I'd rather pay to have someone else only work on that, just like they also pay to have a cloud provider that does that, just like they also don't build the hardware but have someone do it for them. Everyone does their little part well, and they all get tied together.

The sad part about having all these free* open source tools is they are pretty much relegated to hobby developers or tech enthusiasts. They never go mainstream and companies never adopt them. Coming to companies, even though there is exact replica of tool in free open source they won't adopt it reason being support. Companies want a reliable software that has a constant support which unfortunately open source don't provide. They rather pay for WinRar than using free software like 7zip, cause for Winrar there is a dedicated team and if any issue they can contact them and correct it.

And let's not forget about security, an X company provides a tool so usually it is expected to have the best security standards (even though they don't). And if there is any breach they can simply correct it and update the system.
The same thing cannot be said about the open source, there is no benchmark that says it is safe and has best security practices. And even if there is a breach, who is going to support it and correct it?

These are few things that prevent the companies from using or even looking at these free tools. Hope sometime in the future this changes.

author: @jurajkovac8507
text:
Yeah, okay. Needs vary and if you're happy self-hosting and self-managing an open source solution, all the power to you!
However, if you're big enough to pay for Salesforce, then your needs probably also require serious scaling, customization and support. All of that costs money on top of the infrastructure. Is it really more economical to maintain a team of people just to keep your tools alive?

Even when I was a small business owner, we went for Microsoft 365 SMB. Could I host and manage my own email server? Probably. Do I want to spend my time on that? Absolutely not. It's easy to portray SaaS as a greedy money grab, but there's usually an added value aspect that's not easy to appreciate unless you try to go intependent and on-prem.

It's also a little misleading to act like all of these are simple drop-in replacements. Sure, you can swap Adobe CC for a bunch of different apps, but you lose a great deal of consistency. I don't even use Adobe's online services, but I still find it useful how seamlessly I can move between InDesign, Illustrator and Photoshop. You can give this up, but you're trading saved money for added misery.

text: Here's why I pay for MS Office for my staff: My staff cost me an average of $8000/month each.
